description.narrative: SMART Education Project aims to promote awareness, safety and opportunities for migrant children from Myanmar through the knowledge on child rights and safe migration, reducing their vulnerability and exploitation as well as providing access to recognized education programs Problem analysis Thailand, especially Tak Province, has been a destination and transit country for refugees and migrants from Myanmar for decades as they flee conflict and extreme poverty in their home country. Many stay for extended periods and often bring their spouses and children with them. Of course, migrant children are the most vulnerable group who have high risk of exploitation, abuse and denied from the opportunities Project objectives, 1.    Providing capacity building for youth leaders and civil society organizations 2.    Ensuring youth are empowered with the understanding of safe migration and child protection among the wider communities 3.    Supporting a safe learning environment for migrant students from Myanmar in Mae Sot. 4.    Facilitating the coordination between stakeholders and partners in the NFPE and FME programs 5.    Equipping and empowering Migrant School teachers from Myanmar in their role as teachers 6.    Monitoring and evaluation to assure that the standards of NFPE and NFME programs are implemented Project main activities TOT training, develop modules, raising awareness, campaign, support alternative education for migrant learning centers Expected results 1.    Improved skills and capacities of HWF staff, youth leaders and CBO representatives on safe migration 2.    Migrants children and youth demonstrated greater knowledge and understanding on safe migration 3.    Migrant children have a better future opportunity through the recognized alternative education program 4.    Increased collaboration among teachers and key stakeholders in Myanmar for better education   Main thematic Safe migration, human trafficking, child rights
This project mainly contributes to results within Empowerment of human rights defenders. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
